channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. Their looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites and a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose).

item.title: Senior Perl Developer + NLP = Yes, Please! EU remote role
item.description: Our client is a global leader in machine intelligence, and they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) whiz who has experience maintaining and improving large Perl applications and tooling ecosystems. From Finland to the Faroe Islands, this remote role is open to senior Perl developers who are within two hours of Amsterdam’s time zone.

item.title: Are you at the head of the pack? Chief Software Architect role in Malaysia/Dubai/Malta/or elsewhere
item.description: You may be the Chief Software Architect we’re looking for. Ideally, you are located in Malaysia. With offices in Malta or Dubai, these countries are also options. Not located in one of these three spots? We still want to hear from you, and so does our client. Strong leaders aren’t tied to a geographic location.

item.title: Wanna be Flatmates? Perl role in Manchester
item.description: Our client connects people in the UK and US seeking flatmates or homes to share. And that’s where you come in. These flatmate matchmakers need a Software Developer (Backend) to increase the delivery capacity of their core team. You’ll develop and extend RESTful next-generation APIs and use MySQL database to gather data and create customized reusable reports.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer with Cross-Trained Chops. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Fixing Some Bugs in My GitHub Profile Generator
PWC 177
item.description: Thorough discussion of the second task is the highlight for me. Keep it up great work.

item.title: The Palindromic Prime Cyclops Algorithm
item.description: Simon pointed out very interesting aspect of the second task. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Damm Cyclops
item.description: This week Roger kindly discussed Perl and few other solutions in the blog post. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Damm and Cyclops
item.description: A very interesting discussion about the second task. Worth checking it out. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: No one can beat Luis in Perl one-liner. Clever hack used to get the job done. Well done.
Damn numbers!
item.description: Well documented solutions as always by Luca. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 177: Damm Algorithm and Palindromic Prime Cyclops
item.description: We are lucky once again to have so many different guest languages. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: PWC177 - Palindromic Prime Cyclops
item.description: Blog post style is like 2-way communications. You never get bored reading. Great work.

item.title: PWC177 - Damm Algorithm
item.description: I noticed the blog post is more about Raku solution than the Perl. Anyway I enjoy it. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 177
item.description: Just love the extra effort put in the second task. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: One Eye on the Primetime Slot
item.description: Compact solution to the task, easy to follow. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Yet Another Damm Algorithm
item.description: Always pleasure to have dedicated blog post for each task. Well crafted blog post. Well done.

item.title: Cyclops Be Dammed
item.description: Detailed analysis with links to the documentation, helps to understand the code better. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Cyclops Validation
item.description: Short and sweet notes about the weekly challenge. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 171
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 177
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Damm Algorithm" and "Palindromic Prime Cyclops Numbers" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 178
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Quater-imaginary Base" and "Business Date". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Please relicense from "Perl 5" to MIT or Apache 2.0 license
Cryptopals 8 - Detect AES in ECB mode
item.description: This challenge is about sifting through a bunch of lines in a provided file and see which represents something encrypted with AES-ECB. There is, apparently, exactly one such line.

item.title: Cryptopals 7 - AES in ECB mode
item.description: After a little detour to build our own AES toy implementation, we're finally ready for addressing Challenge 7.

item.title: 4 Unrelated Perl Tidbits
item.description: Some fun parts of perl

item.title: AES - Higher level functions
item.description: Our implementation now has a useable way to encrypt and decrypt stuff according to the AES standard, although it’s not very straightforward. We can do better from a useability point of view.

item.title: AES - Cipher
item.description: At this point, we have all the moving parts we need to assemble the Cipher function, let's go!

item.title: Regex basics
item.description: "It's an introduction to the basics of regular expressions. There are many like it, but this is mine."

item.title: #577 - Optimism and numbers
item.description:
Hi there!

last week Mohammad expressed his optimism about Perl rising again. It's nice to have a gut feeling about that, but I would also like to see the numbers. So I looked at the stats I've been collecting for a while: The number of visits to CPAN. More specifically these are the number of "entrances" to MetaCPAN (and in earlier times to SCO as well.) as measured by Google Analytics.

My assumption is that we can measure well the level of Perl usage by the number of visits to MetaCPAN.

The number for July 2022 does not indicate any (positive) changes, but it is probably too early to see any effects anyway.

However, looking at the numbers I noticed that there was a nice increase in the activity in 2012. Actually starting in August 2011. This increased activity lasted about a year then the decline continued and by 2014 the activity was below that of the 2011 level.

I could find 2 Perl-related events preceding the increased activity. In May 2011 the release of perl 5.14 and in July the opening of MetaCPAN. Neither seem to explain the change. So I am turning to you:

What other things happened in or out of the Perl community that might explain that sudden increase of visitors to CPAN?

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: editorial
